question: Under Vision 2020, to check visual acuity, teacher will refer school child to
exp: Under Vision 2020, to check visual acuity, teacher will refer school child to Vision Centre Vision 2020 Right to Sight Major aim - eliminate avoidable blindness by 2020. They are Global India 1. topic_name: NCDs: CHD, HTN, DM, RF, Cancers, Obesity, Blindness

question: Arrange the following causes of NCD deaths as per decreasing order of frequency? A. Cancers B. Cardiovascular diseases C. Diabetes D. Respiratory diseases
exp: The four main NCDs are cardiovascular diseases, cancers, diabetes and chronic lung diseases. The leading causes of NCD deaths in 2016 were Cardiovascular diseases ( 44% of all NCD deaths) Cancers (22% of all NCD deaths) Respiratory diseases, including asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (9% of all NCD deaths). Diabetes caused another 1.6 million deaths.
topic_name: NCDs: CHD, HTN, DM, RF, Cancers, Obesity, Blindness

question: Which of the following is prophylactic treatment of Rheumatic hea disease?
exp: Prevention of rheumatic fever/ hea disease: Type Adults Children Remarks Primary prevention Benzathine benzyl Penicillin 1.2 million unit Benzathine benzyl Penicillin 600,000 units Single dose intramuscular Secondary prevention Benzathine benzyl Penicillin 1.2 million unit Benzathine benzyl Penicillin 600,000 units Recommendations for duration of secondary penicillin prophylaxis: Category Duration 1. Rheumatic fever without carditis - At least for 5yrs since last episode/ until 18 yrs of age ; whichever is longer. 2. Rheumatic fever with carditis ; without residual hea / valvular disease - At least for 10yrs since last episode/ until 25 yrs of age ; whichever is longer. 3. Rheumatic fever with carditis & residual hea disease - At least for 10yrs since last episode/ until 40yrs /until lifelong.
topic_name: NCDs: CHD, HTN, DM, RF, Cancers, Obesity, Blindness

question: Body mass index of a person whose weight is 89 kg and height is 172 cms is:
exp: Body mass index : Is an indicator of obesity: where weight is in kilograms and height is in metres . BMI = weight (kg) /height (m2) = 89/1.72x1.72 = 30
topic_name: NCDs: CHD, HTN, DM, RF, Cancers, Obesity, Blindness

question: What is the Goal of Prudent diet for prevention of Coronary hea disease?
exp: Goal of WHO Prudent diet is to Reduce Cholesterol: HDL ratio <3.5 Prudent diet: Dietary modification is the principle preventive strategy in the prevention of CHD. WHO recommended changes: Reduction of fat intake to <20-30% of total energy intake Consumption of saturated fats <7% of total energy intake Reduction in cholesterol intake to <200 mg/day Increase in complex carbohydrate consumption Reduction of salt intake to < 5 gms per day Avoidance of alcohol consumption. Extra edge: Balanced diet contain: Proteins -10-15 % of daily energy intake Fats - 15-30 % Carbohydrates - constitute remaining energy.
topic_name: NCDs: CHD, HTN, DM, RF, Cancers, Obesity, Blindness

question: Morbid obesity is defined if BMI is greater than:
exp: Most prevalent form of malnutrition: obesity BMI >40: Grade III obesity BMI > 50: super obesity

question: Obesity is BMI greater than:-

topic_name: NCDs: CHD, HTN, DM, RF, Cancers, Obesity, Blindness

question: There are 40 new cases of carcinoma of breast per 100,000 women/ year in country 'X' & 100 new cases / 100,000 women/ year in Country 'Y'. Based on this statistical data which of the following statement is true?
exp: Age is the most impoant risk factor for breast cancer Breast cancer is uncommon below age of 35, its incidence is increasing rapidly b/w ages of 35 to 50. A slight bimodal trend in the age distribution has been observed with a dip in incidence at the time of menopause. A secondary rise in frequency often occurs after the age of 65. Women who developed their first breast cancer under the age of 40, had three times the risk of developing a second breast cancer than those who developed their first cancer after the age of 40 Indeed the etiologies of pre-menopausal & post-menopausal breast cancer appears to be different. Other Risk factors of breast cancer: Family history of breast cancer Delayed first pregnancy Early menarche and late menopause Elevated estrogen & progesterone levels Prior breast biopsy Higher socio-economic status Radiation exposure etc.
opa: More women in Country 'Y' are smokers
opb: More women in Country 'X' had breastfed their children
opc: Country 'X' has more number of younger women than country 'Y'
opd: More preventive & screening measures like mammography are available in Country 'X'
topic_name: NCDs: CHD, HTN, DM, RF, Cancers, Obesity, Blindness

question: Height independent obesity index:
exp: - So, Corpulence Index is "Height independent " index of obesity; cutoff <= 1.2. Other indices depend on height: Broca's index =Ht -100

question: Mr. Murali has 126 mg/dl of fasting plasma glucose. His venous plasma glucose 2h after ingestion of 75g oral glucose load is 149 mg/dl. This patient comes under which stage of WHO diagnostic criteria of diabetes & intermediate hyperglycemia?
exp: WHO recommendations for diagnostic criteria for diabetes & intermediate hyperglycemia: Diagnosis Fasting plasma glucose 2-hr plasma glucose after ingestion of 75g oral glucose load Diabetes >=7.0 mmol/L or 126 mg/dl > 11.1 mmol/L or 200 mg/dl Impaired Glucose Tolerance < 7.0 mmol/L or 126 mg/dl >= 7.8 & < 11.1 mmol/L or b/w 140 mg/dL to 200 mg/dL Impaired Fasting Glucose (IFG) 6.1 to 6. 9 mmol/L or 110 mg/dL to 125 mg/dL < 7.8 mmol/L or 140 mg/dL - Hence, as per the WHO criteria, Murali has impaired glucose tolerance
topic_name: NCDs: CHD, HTN, DM, RF, Cancers, Obesity, Blindness

question: STEPS is done for:
exp: STEPS is stepwise approach for 1. Chronic Disease Risk factor surveillance 2. Stroke Surveillance Core Expanded STEP 1 Tobacco, Alcohol, Diet , Physical activity H/O | BP , H/O DM STEP 2 Height , wt. , waist , BP Hip circumference HR STEP 3 Blood glucose , Blood lipids TG HDL
opa: Surveillance of risk factors of non-communicable disease
opb: Surveillance of incidence of non-communicable disease
opc: Surveillance of evaluation of treatment of non-communicable disease
opd: Surveillance of moality from non-communicable disease
topic_name: NCDs: CHD, HTN, DM, RF, Cancers, Obesity, Blindness

question: Which one of the following statements about influence of smoking on risk of Coronary hea disease is not true?
exp: Relationship between smoking and coronary hea disease:- Influence of smoking in independent of other risk factors for CHD Influence of smoking is synergistic to other risk factors for CHD Influence of smoking is directly related to number of cigarettes smoked per day Influence of smoking is more than additive to other risk factors for CHD.
opa: Influence of smoking is independent of other risk factors for CHD
opb: Influence of smoking is only additive to other risk factors for CHD
opc: Influence of smoking is synergistic to other risk factors for CHD
opd: Influence of smoking is directly related to number of cigarettes smoked per day
topic_name: NCDs: CHD, HTN, DM, RF, Cancers, Obesity, Blindness

question: Percentile BMI for defining as Underweight is:-
exp: Percentile classification of obesity: Underweight: less than 5th percentile Normal BMI: 5th - 85th percentile Overweight: 85th - 95th percentile Obesity: > 95th percentile.
topic_name: NCDs: CHD, HTN, DM, RF, Cancers, Obesity, Blindness

question: According to WHO, blindness there is inability to count fingers at a distance of:
exp: WHO defines blindness as 'visual acuity of <3/60 better eye with best possible correction' National programme for control of blindness India defines Blindness as 'visual acuity of <3/60 in better eye with best possible correction' WHO categories of Visual Impairment: Low vision <6/18 - 6/60 Economic blindness <6/60 - 3/60 - work vision Social blindness <3/60 - 1/60 - walk vision Manifest blindness < 1/60 - Perception of Light + Absolute blindness Perception of Light -ve, unspecified causes
topic_name: NCDs: CHD, HTN, DM, RF, Cancers, Obesity, Blindness

question: Base population for a population based cancer registry is:-
exp: There are mainly two types of cancer registry functional in India. HOSPITAL BASED REGISTRIES: The hospital-based registry indudes all patients treated by a paicular institution, whether inpatients or out-patients. Registries should collect uniform minimum set of data recommended in the '"WHO Handbook for Standardized Cancer Registers". If there is a long-term follow-up of patients, hospital-based registries can be of considerable value in the evaluation of diagnostic and treatment programmes. Since hospital population will always be a selected population, the use of these registries for epidemiological purposes is thus limited. POPULATION-BASED REGISTRIES : A right step is to set up a "hospital-based cancer registry" and extend same to a ''population-based cancer registry". The role is to cover the complete cancer situation in a given geographic area. The optimum size of base population for a population based cancer registry is in the range of 2-7 million. The data from such registries alone can provide the incidence rate of cancer and serve as a useful tool for initiating epidemiological enquiries into causes of cancer, surveillance of time trends, and planning and evaluation of operational activities in all main areas of cancer control.
topic_name: NCDs: CHD, HTN, DM, RF, Cancers, Obesity, Blindness

question: Evidence of decreased risk of Cardiovascular disease is associated with all of the following except:
exp: Factors decreasing risk of cardiovascular diseases: Regular physical activity Dietary goals like decreased salt, cholesterol intake Low to moderate daily alcohol consumption Potassium *Vitamin E supplementation are not associated with a proven benefit of decreased cardiovascular risk. Although some aicles do cite a protective role of Vitamin E because of it's antioxidant action, there is no strong evidence to our Vitamin E supplementation.
opb: Low to moderate daily alcohol consumption
topic_name: NCDs: CHD, HTN, DM, RF, Cancers, Obesity, Blindness

question: Occupational exposure to Benzene may lead to:
exp: Benzene is known to cause cancer, based on evidence from studies in both people and lab animals. The link between benzene and cancer has largely focused on leukemia and other cancers of blood cells.
topic_name: NCDs: CHD, HTN, DM, RF, Cancers, Obesity, Blindness

question: "Early warning signs of Cancer" that public should be beware of include all except :-
exp: Early warning signs of Cancer:- Unexplained loss of weight Lump/hard area in breast Change in wa/mole Persistive change in digestive / bowel habits Persistent cough or hoarsness Excessive cough of blood at monthly period or loss of blood outside usual dates Blood loss from any natural orifice Swelling or sore not getting better.
opb: Lump or hard area in breast
topic_name: NCDs: CHD, HTN, DM, RF, Cancers, Obesity, Blindness

question: MRFIT clinical trial for CHD was conducted in which country?
exp: - The Multiple Risk Factor Intervention Trial (MRFIT) was one of the coronary hea disease prevention trials recommended to the National Hea and Lung Institute in 1971 as an alternative to a national single-factor dietary trial, which was judged to be infeasible. - MRFIT carried out in USA was aimed at high risk adult males aged 35-57 years.
topic_name: NCDs: CHD, HTN, DM, RF, Cancers, Obesity, Blindness
